The '''Caloyers''' (from the [[Greek language|Greek]] ''kalos ghÃ©rÃ´n'', "good old men"), also spelled '''Calogers''' or '''Calogeri''', are [[Greek]] [[monk]]s who follow the rule of Saint [[Basil of Caesarea]]. Both male and female, they particularly inhabit [[Mount Athos]] (only men), but have disseminated throughout all the churches of the East. They live either in monasteries, as at Mount Athos and [[Meteora]] or insulated in [[wiktionary:hermitage|hermitages]], devoted to [[agriculture]] and [[prayer]].
There has never been any reform among them; they still retain their original institution and keep their former habits, with minute exactness. [[Jean-Baptiste Tavernier|Tavernier]] observed that they live an isolated, austere life, eating no meat, and maintaining four [[lent]]s, besides numerous other fasts, with great strictness: they eat no food till they have earned it by the labor of their hands. During their lents, some don't eat more than once in three days, others only twice in seven.
